name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

This type of memory does not allow modification of any individual element, but it enables you to extract a portion of the array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset, and place it back into the same position.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: you may choose arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment, then you substitute the segment a[l … r] with its cyclic shift to the left by any chosen offset d. Moreover, the idea of a cyclic shift can be further clarified with these relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]; this segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of the original elements of the segment, so in the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Arrange the given array a utilizing no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to lessen the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5

Output

1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example:

  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and the shift operations.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of shifts and the shift operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                if min_index != i + 1:
                    l = i + 1
                    r = min_index + 1
                    d = r - l
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                if min_index > i + 1:
                    actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, min_index - i))
                    a[i:min_index + 1] = a[i:min_index + 1][min_index - i:] + a[i:min_index + 1][:min_index - i]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # If the array is already sorted, no actions are needed
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the position of the smallest unsorted element
            min_index = i + a[i:].index(min(a[i:]))
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l

                segment = a[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        # Append the result for the current test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output results
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts and returns the operations performed.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and a list of operations.
        Each operation is represented as a tuple (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the position of the correct element
                correct_pos = a.index(sorted_a[i], i)
                
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the correct element to the current position
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Calculate the shift distance
                    d = correct_pos - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    a[i:correct_pos+1] = a[i+1:correct_pos+1] + [a[i]]
                    # Record the action
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

        for i in range(n - 1):

                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the actions taken.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of actions and the actions themselves.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # If the array is already sorted, no actions are needed
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple sorting strategy using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts within given constraints.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions needed to sort the array.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # If the array is already sorted, no actions are needed
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This strategy is not optimal but ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n
        for i in range(n - 1):
            if a[i] > a[i + 1]:
                # Find the smallest element in the unsorted part
                min_index = i + 1
                for j in range(i + 1, n):
                    if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                        min_index = j

                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the smallest element to the correct position
                if min_index > i:
                    # Calculate the offset for the cyclic shift
                    offset = min_index - i
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = a[i:min_index + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    a[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, offset))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details for each test case.

    Args:
        t: The number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = a.index(sorted_a[i], i)
                if correct_pos != i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = r - l
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+d:r] + a[l-1:l-1+d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions.
        Each action is represented as a tuple (l, r, d) indicating the boundaries and offset of the cyclic shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # If the array is already sorted, no actions are needed
        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i + a[i:].index(min(a[i:]))
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, min_index - i))
                a[i:min_index + 1] = a[i:min_index + 1][min_index - i:] + a[i:min_index + 1][:min_index - i]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the operations performed.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, each containing the number of operations and the operations themselves.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue

        # Simple approach to sort using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i:] != sorted_array[i:]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                # Find the offset to shift
                d = segment.index(sorted_array[i]) + 1
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                operations.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, operations = result
        print(k)
        for op in operations:
            print(f"{op[0]} {op[1]} {op[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
